title: Most beautiful U&Lc G/g
content:
Looking to source the most beautiful U&Lc G/g

I know the publication of that same name had a fetish for the lower case ‘g’ from chesterfield.

what are your favoutites?
author: flex

comments.content:
I’m not sure if I fully understand your question. Are you referring to the “U&lc” publication or to just U/lc in general?

If you are curious to poll personal favs for best uppercase “G” and lowercase “g,” then at this moment I have no “favourites.”

Past faces that I truly admired the design of “G” and “g” are:

Serif: [ITC Galliard Italic](http://web.archive.org/web/20051127125142/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/itc-galliard/italic/testdrive.html?s=G+g&p=72) by Matthew Carter

Sans Serif Display: [Kabel](http://web.archive.org/web/20051127125142/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/kabel/book/testdrive.html?s=G+g&p=72) by Rudolph Koch, Linotype

i referred to both upper and lower case and U&Lc the publication.

and yes was looking for a poll or those, as you state, that you truly admired the design of

Certainly not the most “beautiful” (except maybe to a goth),  
but to me this is the best glyph I myself have designed:

[http://www.themicrofoundry.com/other/Brutaal-g.gif](http://web.archive.org/web/20051127125142/http:/www.themicrofoundry.com/other/Brutaal-g.gif)

hhp

Gee, Hrant,  
it’s a good thing designs aren’t cast in metal anymore or else someone could get hurt by that “g”
I’m not sure if this [**“g”**](http://web.archive.org/web/20051127125142/http:/www.goodwillomaha.com/GWLogoF_C.jpg) can look good, but a least it looks happy.
